subjectData.thoughts: Honestly, I don't really know what I think. It was sometimes hard to make a decision since I associated the people in each scenario with numbers and not with actual people. I also think maybe I choose different things for similar scenarios but I do not know why (although I think my reasoning was pretty similar most of the time).
subjectData.strategies: Depending on the situation equality is more important like in the case of the bail or the respirators. I usually wanted each group to have the same opportunities, however, if making everyone equal decreased the total number of people that got the opportunity by a lot then I would prioritize the scenario in which most people got the opportunity. For the job scenario, it makes more sense to have an equal amount of people from each group rather than the highest number of people because you need a diverse pool of candidates to choose the best one.
subjectData.userAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_15_2) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/80.0.3987.149 Safari/537.36

trials.prompt: Meals on Wheels is tasked with delivering meals to homebound persons. Their time and resources are limited, and some groups live further away, so delivering to some groups may mean less deliveries to others. The numbers below represent how many meals are given to each group. How should they allocate their time for deliveries?

A corporate recruiter is seeking to fill a position at their company. They have limited recruiting budget, and each group uses different job search services, each with different success rates at delivering qualified applicants. The values below show the number of applicants in each group for a fixed advertising budget. How should they allocate their advertising dollars?

A local hospital has a shortage of respirators for patients during the COVID-19 outbreak. Some patients are more likely to be on respirators for longer than others, so less patients will be able to use one. The numbers below represent the number of patients receiving respirators. How should the hospital allocate their respirators?

Meals on Wheels is tasked with delivering meals to homebound persons. Their time and resources are limited, and some groups live further away, so delivering to some groups may mean less deliveries to others. The numbers below represent how many meals are given to each group. How should they allocate their time for deliveries?

A local newspaper company is trying to decide how to divide up the paper routes. Some groups of delivery people are faster than others, and if too many papers don't get delivered, customers get angry. Giving more to one delivery group may mean less for others. The icons below show how many routes are given to each group. How should they divide up the routes?
